Bioshock Infinite has been, and continues to be, a game that keeps on giving to me. Each playthrough reveals something new, with just about every second still feeling enchanting regardless of how many times I stroll through it. It's almost a shame there are a few things holding it back from replacing Bioshock (2007) as my favorite game of all time.   

Here are the Nifty things I liked, and the Lame things I didn't.

[h1]The Nifty[/h1]
✪ I always have, and still very much do love the way this game tackles story-telling. In a sense, it brings back a lot of what made the original Bioshock's story so fantastic, then cranks it up to 11 in every area besides the pseudo first-person narrative. By that, I mean even though you're playing as a character with an established name and purpose, the original Bioshock's lack of making that identity clear made it feel like a more personal experience.

✪ In addition to that, this game does a fantastic job setting itself up for multiple runs. A lot of heavily story-driven games feel boring when I go back to play them again. However, with Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite, I'm always noticing something I missed in prior runs, learning new stuff and experiencing the game in a different way than I did before.

✪ The music is top notch. Almost every licensed song you hear either elaborates upon the situation you're currently experiencing, or provides a bit of foreshadowing that you might not notice until one of your next playthroughs. 

✪  While on the subject of music, Frédéric Chopin's "Nocturne in E-Flat Major, Op. 9, No. 2" can be heard in several parts of the game. I'll always be dishing out bonus points for that one.

✪ Bioshock Infinite's combat may not be as extensive as the last two games, but it's still immensely satisfying and brings back good ideas from each; mostly Bioshock 2. Much like the aforementioned game, we're able to use [strike]plasmids[/strike] vigors at the same time as our firearms. We're also able to utilize two different versions of each, and combine vigors for more effective combat techniques.

✪ Though it's a DLC that must be purchased separately unless you bought the collection, Burial at Sea is a must play. Its setting, pace and gameplay mechanics are all fantastic, with a necessary expansion on not just Infinite's story, but also the original Bioshock's.  

[h1]The Lame[/h1]
✘ Getting this game to run well, despite having a pretty solid rig that should easily handle it on the highest settings, was a tad irritating. In order to access ideal settings, I had to follow [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=203916658] this guide[/url], then spend almost an hour tweaking my mouse's sensitivity settings in not just the game, but the device's control center (iCUE, for the sake of referencing). 

Without doing all of this, even the slightest movements from my mouse caused a stuttering effect on my screen, the interface was far too small for me to see most of the time and my FOV, which I usually prefer being high as possible, only would have increased 15%. Sure, that last one is just me being picky, but the rest still stands. It was borderline unplayable without making a lot of adjustments.

✘ You get plasmids in the form of vigors, run around a city that can only exist in fiction and are met with plot devices that scream "BIOSHOCK", but this, especially compared to the other entries in the franchise, is not a Bioshock game. There is so much missing from the original formula that it almost entirely feels like a canonical spin-off rather than the prequel/sequel this game strives to be, and for those wondering why people dislike Bioshock Infinite so much; that's it, most of the time. 

I could go into more elaborate detail explaining the dozens of things that made Bioshock 1 and 2 greater from a gameplay perspective. but instead, I'll simply say this; Bioshock Infinite is a game that is blatantly tailored toward telling an immersive story, which was designed to be enjoyable multiple times over, than being an immersive game.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Even if it's not quite the Bioshock game many expected, including myself, Bioshock Infinite is still a near-perfect experience. All you have to do is stop comparing it to what you knew and accept it for what it is rather than what it was expected to be. It might not be my favorite game of all time like the original was, but it tells my absolute favorite story; especially when you toss Burial at Sea into the mix.

123打完，海葬没过。感觉剧情一般。简单来说 我觉得过誉了。这个过誉当然是说没有那么多人吹的那么好，但其实也不坏，算是款优秀的游戏，少了南方公园里的调侃，多了些严肃的敏感的话题。游戏的内核其实在诉说一种普世价值，乌托邦嘛，2代结尾有个goodend我很喜欢，也许世人还没有准备好迎接我的到来。毕竟民族主义不消失，民族国家不消失，这些都是无稽之谈。
总之嘛，1 2 部我都自觉的贡献了眼泪，但第三部...少了些情感，多了些无奈。宿命论嘛，看看可以，全信就随意了。另。里面的刷刷刷当然不快乐。

A worthy successor to the first Bioshock, Bioshock Infinite is one of my all time favourite games of all time. High-octane, rewarding gameplay; compelling characters, and an absolutely spell binding story. 10/10.

I absolutely recommend this for all players, but especially intelligent ones. The combat mechanics were fun, and had the same feel as the previous Bioshock games, the worldbuilding and architecture is brilliant and beautiful. the soundtrack is lots of fun, and the voice acting very well done. story was well rounded, and easy to empathise with characters made for a very satisfying playthrough. i will definitely be replaying this, i intend to go for every achievement.

游戏总得来说挺好，没觉得有啥问题，整体玩得都挺爽。
本体和dlc一概选择困难难度。在本体，我装备选择的是血量低杀死敌人回血以及近战回血，异能常用吸收伤害，大大降低容错率！武器感觉都不太给力，一般带卡宾枪和霰弹枪，但是卡宾枪杀伤力不太强，霰弹枪杀伤距离又太近（这游戏远程敌人还蛮多），头疼。打通关后无意中在游民某个评论区看到一个及其牛逼的打法（最后一关齐柏林飞艇），就是把那个吸收子弹的异能（正式叫“以牙还牙”？）往能量柱上一扔，轻轻松松过关！反正我是扔了七八个把能量柱围了个严实，结束的时候还有一半多的血量（估计受到的伤害是被火炮打的）。

海葬1似乎跟本体玩法差异不大，只是伊丽莎白的补给少了太多，打法基本都一样。魅惑异能消耗大大降低，闪电等伤害技能消耗跟本地的魅惑差不多，升级满了也只能扔个四五发。

海葬2的话，一定要拿到那个不移动则隐身无消耗的mod，简直太牛逼了！敌人在你身边转来转去发现不了你，然后等警戒等级降为黄色后来上一轮子，接着立马隐身，依此循环。有了这mod，通关简直不要太轻松！！！具体在哪记不清了，但是这个mod需要用异能冰冻降温才能拿到，整个dlc好像就两个mod需要这样才能解开。

本体、海葬一二部的结局都比较蛋疼，某种意义来说都是BadEnding，游玩过后心情有点忧郁。
接下来玩1，2代去咯~~

El unico juego que realmente me ha dejado boca abierta y sin aliento en algunas ocasiones en la narrativa, siendo posiblemente algo complejo de entender con los universos paralelos y sus efectos en otros, aunque en caso de que te quedes atorado en algunas partes de la historia, los DLC "Burial At Sea" te los complementa para tener una mejor interpretacion de las acciones.

En conclusion: uno de esos juegos (yo lo considero de los unicos juegos que existen actualmente) en los que debes de jugar mas de una o dos veces su historia para que logres conectar puntos y puedas saber el contexto que Ken Levine le trato de dar al juego. (Puede que no sea el perfecto pero si el mejor que he visto)
